raw_text:
Brown visits slum on Africa trip
 
 Chancellor Gordon Brown has visited Kenya's biggest shantytown as he opened a week-long visit to Africa.
 
 Mr Brown's trip is designed to highlight how the UK wants to make Africa's problems a priority of its chairmanship of the G8 this year. He will see an HIV/Aids orphanage in Tanzania and a women's credit union in Mozambique before chairing a meeting of the Commission for Africa in Cape Town. At slums in Narobi on Wednesday, he said education needs had to be tackled.
 
 Speaking outside the Olympic Primary School, Mr Brown said: "It is simply not acceptable in the modern age for the rest of the world to stand by and have hundreds of millions of children not getting the chance at education." He pointed to international plans to invest $10bn for education in Africa over the next decade. The school is on the edge of Kibera, where 800,000 live often in huts made of mud, scrap metal and cardboard. Mr Brown's aides say he wants to find out more about the Kenyan Government's education policies, which included introducing free primary education in early 2003. The chancellor has already unveiled proposals for a G8 aid package which he has likened to the Marshall Plan used by the United States to rebuild Europe after World War Two. The trip follows claims of infighting between Mr Brown and Tony Blair detailed in a new book. Conservative leader Michael Howard is expected to seize on those reports at prime minister's questions at 1200 GMT on Wednesday.
llama3.2:1b: Chancellor Gordon Brown visits Kenya's slums as part of his week-long Africa trip, where he aims to highlight the UK's efforts to address African problems during its G8 chairmanship this year.
He will visit an HIV/AIDS orphanage and a women's credit union in Tanzania and Mozambique, and meet with officials at an education commission in Cape Town.

He emphasized education needs must be tackled and announced plans to invest $10bn in Africa over the next decade.
The trip follows reports of infighting between Brown and Blair, and comes ahead of prime minister's questions where Conservative leader Michael Howard is expected to attack Brown over the claims.

His visit is part of the UK's efforts to prioritize Africa as a priority for the G8 this year.

The school where he visits the slums is located on the edge of Kibera, with 800,000 children living there and often using makeshift materials like mud, metal scraps, and cardboard.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Chancellor Gordon Brown embarked on an Africa trip, commencing his journey by visiting Kenya's largest slum, Kibera, with an estimated population of 800,000 living in impoverished conditions.

During this stop, he emphasized the urgent need to address education shortcomings, stating it is unacceptable for the global community to ignore hundreds of millions of children lacking access to education.
Brown also highlighted international commitments of $10 billion towards African education over the next decade.
The visit underscores the UK's intention to prioritize Africa's challenges as it chairs the G8 this year, with plans for a significant aid package reminiscent of the Marshall Plan.

This trip comes after allegations of tension between Brown and former Prime Minister Tony Blair were detailed in a recent publication, potentially influencing discussions at prime minister's questions by Conservative leader Michael Howard.

He highlighted the need for improved education, citing a $10bn international investment plan.
Brown also plans to visit an HIV/AIDS orphanage in Tanzania and a women's credit union in Mozambique before chairing a Commission for Africa meeting in Cape Town.
His trip follows his proposal for a G8 aid package similar to the Marshall Plan and comes amid reports of political tensions with Prime Minister Tony Blair.
